comments:
I am an experienced java developer, and have been using eclipse for over 3 years. I have just installed Eclipse 3.1.0 onto an acer twin core laptop, running Windows XP service pack 2.

When I try and debug anything (even HelloWorld) I get an instant dialog box "Cannot connect to VM". 

In the log file I get the dump that I display at the bottom of this message.

A search of the Internet reveals that there are two likely candidates: either a firewall, or some clash in the path between different JREs using to compile and run. I have ensured that the only installed JVM is 1.5.0_06, and the path to it is C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.5.0_06. I have disabled the firewall, and still have the issue.

A third theory is that the issue might be caused by an existing piece of software that is bound to the debug port. I performed tests on a working eclipse and believe that the required ports are 2681..2684. I have attached a netstat -a dump, and I think this shows that the ports 2681 to 2684 are free (I am not very experienced in the use of netstat, so I might have misunderstood this)

A fourth theory is that this might be a result of the debug time out, so I have set this to 5000.

I have run out of things to try, so any advice is appreciated.

Thanks

Phil


Here is the .log dump
!ENTRY org.eclipse.jdt.launching 4 120 2006-04-11 23:03:15.812
!MESSAGE Cannot connect to VM
!STACK 0
java.net.BindException: Address already in use: JVM_Bind
	at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.socketBind(Native Method)
	at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.bind(Unknown Source)
	at java.net.ServerSocket.bind(Unknown Source)
	at java.net.ServerSocket.<init>(Unknown Source)
	at java.net.ServerSocket.<init>(Unknown Source)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketTransportService.startListening(SocketTransportService.java:275)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketTransportImpl.startListening(SocketTransportImpl.java:47)
	at org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketListeningConnectorImpl.startListening(SocketListeningConnectorImpl.java:108)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.StandardVMDebugger.run(StandardVMDebugger.java:196)
	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.launch(JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.java:85)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:590)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:515)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch(DebugUIPlugin.java:733)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin$6.run(DebugUIPlugin.java:931)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:76)

Marking as REMIND for more input.
*** Bug 181652 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
The test code given runs w/o errors. Debugging still broken.
Are you able to try a different machine? i.e. to see if debugging works on a different computer.
Others here do not see the problem. My workstation was built within the last month while theirs were built some time ago, so there are likely differences both in software and hardware.

Completely deinstalling JDk / JRE 1.5 "fixed" the issue. Reinstalling JDK 1.5 reinstated the issue. 

I looked at the path. Although I had the 1.4 JDK in the path prior to any 1.5 entries, I did not have the 1.4 jre in the path as well. When I added the 1.4 JRE to the path prior to any 1.5 entries, the problem was fixed, even in the presence of 1.5 installations.

Both 1.4 entries must be in the path prior to any 1.5 entries.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 176471 ***
